Ask HN: What are fair ways to structure a deal with anchor client?
text:
We're a tech company working with large customers (~Fortunate 500). We came across a new software idea but prior to building it, we need one anchor client. We need them to provide access to their data and need them to test out the processes. We recently found one interested client. They are willing to give us access to their system, their data and have us develop a solution.

We need this initial client (their data, and their buy-in), but we also want to own this software and resell it to other Fortune 500 Cos and do not necessarily want to develop this at a complete loss.

What are some fair ways to structure the deal with this initial anchor customer?

Making Blogs Popular Again
text:
Wanting to tell you guys about the app I'm currently building!

For context: I'm someone that enjoys reading blogs, even more than watching TikTok videos, or YouTube videos. I write for fun on Medium, and on Substack.

The problem I'm trying to solve is the decreased popularity of blogs from readers, and writers, especially in younger generations.

I'm building an app that has the social capabilities of Twitter, the recommendation engine of TikTok, and the purpose of Medium.

The app would let you create a TEXT newsletter which would notify your followers when you post a blog, and we would split advertisement revenue with writers.

The goal of this app is to make it a pleasant experience for both readers, and writers. We'll do this by ensuring that readers are receiving content they want to see (recommendation engine). The content goes to you, not the other way around. For writers we're going to ensure that they're compensated properly for their hard work, and are given a great metrics dashboard to see exactly how much they're growing, what demographic, what region, etc. The app would also offer AI assistance, and collaborations with other writers. Writers could use AI to help them finish their story, or help them come up with a story.

I'll be making a follow up post showcasing the design of the app. Who would want to use something like this?

Macro systems comparison
text:
I would like to make a comparison of macro systems of programming languages.

In general, I know that S-expression based Lisp ones are the most powerful, also thanks to Lisp's homoiconic nature.

But in other languages that support good macro system (some of them listed here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Macro_(computer_science)#Syntactic_macros) are they equivalent or some are more powerful than others?

Does the power of the macro system depend on some feature of the language, such as the syntactic structure (like homoiconicity in the case of Lisp) or maybe on the type system?

Ask HN: What are white collar workers supposed to do in the face of LLM/ChatGPT?
text:
Most computer-based office work is taking some input, making sense of it, and outputting some more human-centric transformation of it. Which is what chatgpt/LLM does.

Financial analysts, lawyers & legal aides, accountants, content creation & marketing, sales, customer service, programmers, etc. etc.

This is most of what the middle class does, no? What are people supposed to do instead?

title: Ask HN: Tech Stack Visualization / Monitoring Tool?
text:
Same as title. As a full stack web developer who sometimes procastinate my full-time job to create my personal projects, I wonder if there are any tools out there to visualize and monitor my tech stacks. I want it to be as lightweight as possible, and quickly see the server status (sometimes simply down or up) at each layer (e.g. front-end, back-end, database etc)

I have seen the tool CloudCraft, but it seems to only work with AWS, but I’m running my stacks almost entirely on Netlify / Vercel, so it’s of no use to me.

Any input is hugely appreciated!
